titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Finished reading Lessing’s Emilia Gallotti— In this as in his Sara Sampson, he has thrown the whole burden of woe upon the virtuous— The detestable characters are not punished.— Like most of the German authors, he observes no law of poetical Justice, at all.— Paid a visit this afternoon to the Countess Brühl, with Mrs: Adams. Count Schall, came in while we were there— Doctor Brown and his family passed the Evening and supped with us.— Mr: Arbuthnot was with us a couple of hours.
2. Began Lessing’s junge gelehrte, a comedy, the first that he wrote— At the play this afternoon. Selbstbeherrschung, a new Comedy in 5 Acts of Iffland; excessively dull.

3. Called this morning upon Mr: Garlike who is unwell. At the play again in the Evening. Die Silberne Hochzeit, or the celebration of 25 years marriage, a Comedy of Kotzebue—tolerably good; with a great affectation however of closing every act with a striking situation, and at a critical moment.— The house was thin.

4. Finished this morning the last volume of Buchholz’s history, containing the reign of Frederic 2. untill the Peace of Hubertsbourg in 1763.— I began with this volume as containing the most interesting period, and have read none of the others.— At the Casino towards Evening, an hour— Called with Mrs: A. at Mrs: Brown’s, but she was not at home— Read Gillies— His account of the Pelopponesian War, and the Sedition at Coreyra; they remind me often of the present times.

5. Began the first volume of Buchholz’s History, and read the preface of Mr: Süssmilch.— At the Casino towards Evening. read part of Mallet du Pan’s account of the destruction of the Helvetic league. Half an hour at Mrs: Brown’s—rest of the Evening at home.

6. Read Buchholz’s preface, and began his topographical description of the Electorate of Brandenburg. Letter writing in the forenoon— Walk, though the weather has grown very indifferent. Read largely in Gillies, the Evening through.
7. Rained almost the whole day— Doctor Brown called in the forenoon.— An hour after dinner at the Casino. Evening at home reading Gillies— Finished his second, and began his third volume.

8. Another rainy day which I employed according to usual custom— In the Evening at Bellevue.— The Prince, did not appear— Company small.— Mrs: A. did not go— Whist with Madam de Sartoris, Mlle: Hagen, and the Baron de Rothenbourg.— Upon my return home found letters from Mr: Pitcairn & Mr: King.— Mr: Engeström called upon me this forenoon.
9. Rain again part of the day.— Miss Neale passed the Evening with Mrs: Adams. At the Casino. reading Mallet du Pan’s Mercure Britannique.— Read at home a few pages of Gillies.

10. Finished Buchholz’s topographical description of the mark of Brandenburg, which has given me some further knowledge of the Country and its Government.— Wrote nothing— Walked in the park— Evening at Dr. Brown’s, after spending an hour or two at the Casino— Mr: Courtois at Mr: Brown’s.— Heard that Prince Radziwill’s papers were this day at noon sealed by the Chancellor Goldbeck, and the Ministers Alvensleben & Haugwitz.

11. Began upon Buchholz’s History—the original inhabitants of the Mark, were the Sennones and Longobardi. His principal authority is Tacitus— Read in the forenoon as usual— At the Casino, in the afternoon. Finished Mallet du Pan’s account of the destruction of the Helvetic league— At home and read in the 3d: volume of Gillies.

12. Wrote a little this forenoon— Evening at Bellevue.— The Prince himself is yet ill, and did not appear. Neither was Prince Radziwill present.— The Princess however was there with her children.— Evidently concerned at the circumstance which recently occurred to her husband, as were all the family— Whist with Madame de Grappendorf, Mlle: Hagen & Count Neale— Mr: Livingston & Mr: Arbuthnot, were there.

13. Translating from the German—find it tolerably easy.— Letter to my brother.— In the Evening, read further in Gillies— His account of the death of Socrates remarkably dull.— Perhaps by too closely translating from his original authors.

14. Evening at a large party, at the Baron de Hagen’s.— The first of twenty suppers, to be given twice a week by that number of subscribers, untill the carnaval.— Had some conversation with General Tempelhoff about his History of the 7. years war— He says the 6th: and last volume will appear probably in the course of the next year.— He was present at all the sieges, and almost all the battles of the War, and was led to this work by the wish to vindicate the Prussians against the military criticisms of General Lloyd.— Was an hour at the Casino, in the course of the Evening, and came home to supper.

15. Mrs: Adams unwell with the rheumatism— Reading all the morning and forenoon— A desultory reading before dinner, instead of writing. Miss Borke and Miss Golowkin in the afternoon, and Miss Neale spent the Evening with us.— Letters from Mr: King and Mr: Pitcairn.

16. Called this forenoon upon Mr: Engeström, and Mr: Schickler. Found neither of them at home. Afterwards met Mr: Engeström in the Street.— First snowy weather.— In the afternoon called with Mrs: Adams on Madame Engeström; but found her not at home— Afterwards at the Grande Maitresse of the Queen, Madame de Voss’s, where we found the English Prince Augustus, and his Gentlemen, Messrs: Livingston and Arbuthnot.— He says he swears only by the Queen of Naples.— Remainder of the Evening at the Minister Heinitz’s— Whist with the Princess de Sacken, Madame de Saldern, and Baron Hagen.

17. Called again upon Mr: Schickler this morning, but can succeed in nothing.— Mr: Engeström came, and gave me the bill and Letter for New-York, which I sent on to Pitcairn.— Evening at Madame de Saldern’s— Mrs: A. did not stay— Whist with Madam de Münchhausen, Mlle: Hagen, and Count Byland. Mr: Livingston brought me home—

18. After the usual employment, took a walk in the Park— Afternoon two hours at the Casino— Account of an action between a french and American frigate.— At home reading further in Gillies; an account of the retreat of the ten thousand.

19. Writing to the Secretary of State. Customary walk. Evening at the Princess Henry’s party. Large company. The English Prince Augustus there.— Whist with Madame de Blumenthal, Madame de Reck, and Coll. Zastrow.

20. Called this afternoon at 1/2 past five upon Count Haugwiz, as by appointment to enquire whether a permission can be obtained to export 10,000 muskets for the U.S.— He said that a late change had been made in the muskets used by the troops in this Country, and that six months ago such an exportation could not be permitted because all that the manufacture could deliver were required for the king’s own troops.— That he could not say but would soon enquire and inform me whether the same occasion still exists, and if not, the king would seize with pleasure the opportunity of manifesting his friendly disposition towards the U.S. by readily granting the permission desired.— Visits this afternoon from Count Neale, and his daughter Sophie—from Mr: Livingston and Mr: Arbuthnot.—from Baron Posch and Mr: Cohen, and from two Miss Browns and their brother— Read a little in Gillies at the close of the Evening.

21. Visit this afternoon to Messrs: Livingston and Arbuthnot, but they were not at home. to Lord Talbot, whom I found studying German.— At the play. Die Familie, or Der Deutsche Hausvater, a comedy by the Baron Otto von Gemmingen, was performed, and is pretty good.— After the play at Mr: Cohen’s to supper. Whist there part of the Evening. Company, chiefly Dr: Brown and his family.— Mr: Arbuthnot came while we were at supper.

22. Weather very cold, and the ground covered with Snow. Latter part of the Evening, and supper at Dr: Brown’s— Lord Talbot and Mr: Garlike there— Letter from Mr: Pitcairn— My brother sailed about the 15th: from Glückstadt.— This wind and weather is favourable for him.

23. Cold and Snowy. Dined with Prince Augustus of England. The party was small, consisting only of the Prince’s family, The Englishmen in town, and Baron Ompteda.— The Prince is severely and almost constantly afflicted with an asthmatic complaint.— Evening at home. The two Miss Neale’s with Mrs: Adams.— Translated a fable of Gellert.

24. Snowed almost the whole day.— Evening party at Count Panin’s.— Cards, supper and Ball. The Company quite large.— Played reversi with Madame de Hagen, Madame de Marwitz and Count Podewils.— Danced after supper with the Countess Mary Brühl.— Did not come away till nearly three in the morning. I enquired of the Minister Schroetter whether the Waters of the Baltic constantly fall, as I have somewhere read— He says No. But that they lose, on the Swedish side, and encroach upon the Coast on this side.—

25. Though so late up last night, did not neglect the occupations of this day.— Evening at the king and queen’s Court, which being the first of the Season, upon their return to town was very splendid, and crowded— At Madame de Voss’s—before the court began.— Came home very early.— Letters from Mr: Murray and Mr: Pitcairn, enclosing one from my brother— Who sailed from the mouth of the Elbe on the 19th:

26. A Very cold day.— The young Countess Brühl at tea, and pass’d the Evening with Mrs: A. Mr: Arbuthnot made a short visit— The Princess Henry has no party— The Prince has forbidden her to receive Count Haugwitz on account of Prince Radziwill’s affair.— The king has ordered her to receive him, and ordered Haugwitz to go there every Monday— Between them both the Princess knows not what to do—

27. Very cold again— Tea and part of the Evening with Madame de Sartoris.— Her little girl, four or five years old plays very well upon the forte-piano— Mrs: A. sung— Mr: Arbuthnot was there— Finished this morning the first volume of Buchholz and began the second— Read a little of Gillies in the Evening.

28. The party and supper this Evening at Mr: Dorville’s— Mrs: A. stayed but a few minutes— Whist with Mlle: de Hagen, Madame de Zastrow and M. de Buch.— Came away at nine. supped at Dr: Brown’s— Miss Brühl there. Took Miss Hagen home.

29. Went to the carpet Manufactory, but were too late— It is shut up at noon— To the silversmith’s.— Walk short. The young Countesses Neale and Brühl, pass’d the Evening with Mrs: A.— Letters from Holland.

30. Went again to the carpet manufactory this morning, and in the Evening to the play where we saw, the Enchantress Sidonia, a Comedy bybut more of the tragical than comical character— The plot is atrocious to disgust. Read a little in Gillies after we came home.

Day. The same as last month.— My German reading in the morning is very regular; but advances me little in the language. I have read through the first and begun upon the second volume of Buchholz.— The Evening reading is now very much interrupted, and as the winter comes on, will probably be so yet more.— I am yet in the third volume of Gillies’s History.
